comments.commentBody: Some of you folks seem to take life far too seriously. I feel that ANYTHING that brings a family together or helps us interact with our kids benefits us through casual communication and builds bridges that will be vital to us at some point in our lives. We seem to have a notion that "mindless" gaming is bad or unhealthy. As with anything, only in excess. Many studies have indicated that such mindless activities allow the subconscious "mind" to process more important information. Solutions to difficult problems or situations often come to me if I put them out of my head for a while, and I believe it's equally valuable to children (maybe more so). There seems to be an assumption in the comments that this is the ONLY interaction between father and sons, but why? And would a game of Candyland, Trouble, Risk or any of the countless board games available be viewed as bad? There's plenty of pressure to learn/succeed/achieve/dominate, yet harmless fun creates a man-child. Ok, maybe the guy stays up too late, maybe slightly obsessed, perhaps he's a lot like me (if you score "total destruction" with the Mighty Eagle you get an eagle feather next to your score!) I'm within spitting distance of 50, have NEVER enjoyed electronic games (with the exception of playing some Wii with my daughters), but I'm hooked. And I've only been late for work once since the game came out. (New update for Seasons version in May, can't wait!) So numb out, as long as you numb back in for most of the ride. Building a house takes a lot of "adult" planning and organization these days, but I try to laugh and have some fun while I do it. And teach my daughters a little about geometry, finances, building codes and why we have them,and good hard work.
Fabulous. What an incredible loss.

So I was doing the puzzle while watching The King's Speech and wondering why Geoffrey Rush did not win an Oscar when along came The PIERRE in the puzzle.

The PIERRE is a hotel along Central Park. I stayed there two times. The first time NYC had a blackout and I could not use the elevator. The second time I don't remember because I was blacked out.

Not sure how AIR PIPE slipped past Will S. As a scuba diver, I've never heard this referred to as anything other than the air hose.

Google shows that the one and only online reference to air pipe in relation to scuba mouthpieces appears as an erroneous entry on dictionary.com, which lists the origin of the term as 1665 - three hundred years before the invention of scuba.

I can understand really wanting to use "air pipe" in the grid, but I think a plain clue, e.g., compressed gas conduit, would have been better.

Terrific puzzle with a wonderful theme. My first run-through left me with TIMER at 1A, LEGAL AGE at 19A, HIVE at 21A, ELLS at 28A, HATH at 57A, COATS at 91A, and AGA at 64D. All the pretty easy downs in the NW showed me that a much cleverer interpretation of the 1A clue was called for and got me going in the right direction, so despite such a wealth of erroneousness (wd?) to start with, I managed a win without so much as a hint from Ms. Check. Now I hope I can relax tomorrow and watch the Caps do as well against Tampa Bay.

This seems worse than some of the horrors of Iraq, since we are sure this time that the orders came from the top. NATO got themselves into a war they have no idea how to get out of, and are trying desperately to find a way out by assassinating Gaddafi. It was a craven and cowardly murder. How many more innocents are going to pay with their lives? Regime change isn't legal under international law. Who is the lawless savage, Gaddafi suppressing revolts in his country or the West resorting to murder to push him out? Maybe all those commentators who were lauding this escapade as feminist foreign policy would like to retract their words.

I live in Canada, and I am deeply concerned about our involvement in what seems to have become an undeclared war by NATO against the Libyan government. Canadians need to demand some answers from our own government:

Why is Canadian Lt.-Gen. Charles Bouchard, who is in command of NATO's military operations in Libya, ordering an airstrike on the family of a foreign leader?

On what legal grounds is Canada participating in the overthrow of a foreign government through political assassination--which was clearly the intent of this airstrike?

What are the potential legal consequences for NATO, the Canadian general in charge, and the Canadian government for deliberately killing innocent people in an airstrike that can in no way be considered part of the UN-sanctioned mandate to protect Libyan civilians?

At the outset, many warned that the longer we participate in this civil war, the more we will become the instrument of one side in the conflict. That has now come to pass in the worst possible way--the killing of innocents by NATO. Our moral justification for being militarily involved just evaporated.

The creators of popular entertainment are not interested in advancing social debate or what may or may not be morally/ethically correct. What they are interested in is riding any wave possible in order to make money. That's the long and the short of it.

But then why is there a wave of interest in this and what are the repercussions--intended or not?
Perhaps the interest is a reaction to the fact that, today, women are more likely to be your boss, to hold a position of political or economic clout that previously would have been unthinkable for females. "You've come a long way, baby" is totally true--it's just that what you've come to isn't the panacea you thought it was; that was a lie and always was, regardless of gender.
And the repercussions? Perhaps it allows us to further legitimize women as leaders. It also allows us to share the blame for what goes wrong. So far, though, in fiction and in real life, these are male roles that women take on, thus taking on male functions. We've yet to see--and probably won't see for a long time, if ever--a truely female existence that is as matriarchal as the current world culture is patriarchal.

Anyway, the movies are made for entertainment, I recommend enjoying them as such. Or avoiding them as such--society goes where it will, films (or books or anything else) don't shape it, they reflect what's already there.

Budget airlines are a very good solution if you are not subject to a specific timetable, as many time you can't find a last minute seats.
Service okay if you do not expect too much.
I just hope that savings does not come at the expense of maintenance.
http://www.lifestyle-after50.com/travel.html

Regardless of his now-gone athletic brilliance, what still shines with Jim Brown is his articulate intelligence and his passion for what he believes is right. 30 seconds with Jim Brown is worth 30 minutes with most. Thanks for publishing this!

I would say this pick is likely wasted, unless Patriots are determined to let Brady go when his current contract is up, which I doubt very much. Barring a serious injury to Brady, how would Belichick use (and thus demonstrate the trade value of) Mallet, assuming he develops into a decent pro-football QB? Even if he is the second coming of Bledsoe, I don't think Belichick would choose him over a 37-year old Brady.

A few scenarios this pick may pay off for NE:

(1) As the backup QB, Mallet keeps NE in hunt until Brady is back from injury.
(2) A repeat of Matt Cassel situation, i.e., a season-ending injury to Brady.
(3) A career ending injury to Brady.
(4) The presence of a possible replacement making Brady a better player.

If they are looking for a backup QB, for slightly more cost an experienced but less-gifted QB (in the mold of Kitna) would be preferred as it typically takes a QB who has never started a few games to get comfortable quarterbacking. And none of (2) thru (4) are all that likely. Is it possible that the Pariots strikes gold again in finding their next franchise QB? Not impossible but the odds are slim to none.

I predict that he will be released in his 3rd year with the Patriots.
U txt hr oftn?

I hesitate to post this because it can be remarkably effective. It should only be used for good.

Have an employee at a bookstore walk over to the object of your attention and say, "The gentleman over in fiction would like to buy you a book."

Update:

- Do you read Schott's Vocab on New York Times?

- ...

- Well, they have this Weekend Competition about chat-up lines, do you mind if I try out a few on you?

- ...

- Okay, here we go... You eyes are so pure and beautiful, they fill me with the promise of happiness!

- ...

- Your skin is so beautiful and silky, I want it to be the fabric of my life!

- ...
__________________________________________________

It surely works.
(this probably only works at MLA in January): "Haven't I read your dissertation?"
(miniaturization has ruined a lot of possibilities, such as): "Is that a flash drive in your pocket or are you just glad to see me?"
you're so hot that you are single handedly responsible for global warming, so for the benefit of science and society I am going to need to study you in order to cool you down.
There's something special about you that fills my heart with the desire to do chores for you for the rest of my life. Are you free this weekend? I'd like to get started.
(At most bars in East Texas and one or two in New Jersey): "I didn't know God made honky-tonk angels."

A tv interviewer approached a couple who were amongst the celebratory
throng in the Mall, waiting to catch a glimpse of William and Kate, the royal bridal couple.

The tv guy put his stock question to the couple: "Why did you come here today?"
And their surprise answer was they "had to come" because this is where they first met during the wedding celebration of of William' s mother.

To my chagrin, the pick-up line was not revealed.

Slap me. I'm daydreaming of an angel incarnate.

[Slap]

Good. Now, slap me harder, so that I can dream of my devil tonight.
The ancients got it wrong.  There are 10 muses.
If I don't see you again, swell!
What's Your Major?'
